title: Worked Solution
text:
All of the choices are correct. The discovery of fermented foods likely benefited our ancestors in several ways.

Firstly, fermentation breaks down complex compounds in food, making it more easily digestible. This allowed our ancestors to extract more nutrients from their food and be more efficient in their energy intake.

Secondly, fermentation aided in hunting as it allowed for preservation of meat and other perishable foods, making it possible to travel longer and further without the risk of food spoilage. It also allowed for the creation of alcoholic beverages, which could be used as a source of hydration in the absence of clean water.

Thirdly, fermentation helped to preserve and enhance the taste of food. Fermented foods often have a complex, tangy, and savory taste that is appealing to human taste buds. This allowed our ancestors to enjoy a wider variety of flavors and likely improved their overall dietary quality.

Finally, people could eat less of fermented food and still feel full as the fermentation process produced compounds such as lactic acid, which slows down the digestion process and provides a feeling of satiety.

Overall, the discovery of fermented foods was likely a critical turning point in human history, providing significant benefits such as improved nutrition, food preservation, and new tastes and flavors to enjoy.
